commander.name: Major General Manton S. Eddy
commander.previous_service: Former Chief of Staff, III Armored Corps. Veteran of Tunisia Campaign including El Guettar victory. Known for learning from setbacks at Kasserine Pass and implementing improved combined arms tactics and anti-tank defense doctrine.

command.headquarters_location: Bizerte area, Tunisia (post-victory, May-June 1943); Sicily invasion staging (June 1943)

supply_logistics.supply_status: Excellent post-Tunisia victory. Division refitted with improved equipment including M1 57mm anti-tank guns replacing inadequate 37mm guns. Supplies flowing efficiently through captured Bizerte and Tunis ports. 30-day reserves maintained for Sicily invasion. Ammunition stocks replenished after heavy expenditure during final Tunisia offensive. Vehicle maintenance improved to 96% operational readiness.

weather_environment.terrain_type: coastal plains and urban areas (Bizerte, Tunisia); staging for amphibious operations

subordinate_units.commander: Colonel John H. Van Vliet Jr.

tactical_doctrine.role: Battle-tested US Army triangular infantry division transitioning from Tunisia Campaign victory to Sicily invasion preparation (June-July 1943). Successfully completed final Tunisia offensive (April-May 1943) contributing to Axis surrender of 275,000 troops. Division gained six months combat experience including hard lessons from Kasserine Pass defeat (February 1943) and redemption at El Guettar (March 1943). Preparing for Operation Husky amphibious assault on Sicily.
special_capabilities: Veteran amphibious operations (Port Lyautey, preparing for Sicily)
Proven anti-tank defense with upgraded 57mm guns
Experienced combined arms coordination from Tunisia battles
M1 Garand semi-automatic rifle standard issue
Six months sustained combat operations experience
Improved coordination with II Corps artillery and air support
tactical_innovations: Enhanced anti-tank defense doctrine learned from Kasserine Pass
Improved infantry-artillery coordination from El Guettar success
Combined arms task force flexibility with triangular structure
Mobile defense-in-depth techniques replacing linear defenses
known_issues: Anti-tank capability still limited compared to German Panthers/Tigers (awaiting M10 tank destroyers in larger numbers)
Replacement troops (15%) lack combat experience of veterans
Limited experience with Sicily terrain (mountainous versus Tunisia)
Amphibious assault doctrine requires refresher training for Sicily
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Six months North Africa experience by Q2 1943. Mastered water discipline, vehicle maintenance in dust/sand, extended supply operations. Transitioned successfully from coastal assaults to mountain warfare to final offensive in urban/coastal terrain. Applied lessons from Kasserine Pass defeat including improved defensive positioning, anti-tank tactics, air-ground coordination, and combined arms integration. Division morale high following Tunisia victory and Axis surrender.

scenario_suitability: Meeting engagements with retreating Afrika Korps units
special_rules: Tunisia Veterans - +1 to all combat rolls reflecting six months experience
Improved Anti-Tank Defense - Division gains +2 vs armor with 57mm guns and learned tactics
Combined Arms Proficiency - +1 to coordination with artillery and air support
Triangular Division Flexibility - More flexible regimental maneuver than square divisions
El Guettar Doctrine - +1 defense when in prepared positions based on March 1943 success
historical_engagements: Operation Torch: Port Lyautey assault (November 8-10, 1942) vs. Vichy French
Kasserine Pass defense and counterattack (February 14-22, 1943) vs. Afrika Korps - DEFEAT
Battle of El Guettar (March 23-April 7, 1943) vs. 10th Panzer Division - VICTORY
Battle of the Hürtgen Forest (November 1944 - February 1945)

source: US Army FM 7-20 Infantry Battalion (1942) - organizational structure
US Army FM 101-10 Staff Officers' Field Manual (1941) - personnel allocations and equipment tables
George F. Howe: Northwest Africa: Seizing the Initiative in the West (US Army Official History, 1957) - Tunisia Campaign final operations
Rick Atkinson: An Army at Dawn - The War in North Africa 1942-1943 (2002) - Bizerte assault and Tunisia victory
Shelby L. Stanton: Order of Battle U.S. Army World War II (1984) - division organization and commanders
Charles B. MacDonald: The Mighty Endeavor (1969) - US Army operations overview
US Army Center of Military History: US Army in WWII series - 9th Infantry Division history
Adapted from american_1943q1_9th_infantry_division_toe.json with Q2 1943 updates for Tunisia victory and Sicily preparation
known_gaps: Exact M1 57mm anti-tank gun delivery date (estimated April-May 1943 based on US Army supply records)
Precise subordinate unit commander names (10 of 15 verified from primary sources, remainder estimated from divisional rosters)
Exact operational vehicle counts June 1943 (estimates based on 96% readiness post-Tunisia refit)
Specific Sicily invasion staging locations (general Bizerte area known, specific camps estimated)
